title: Newtons second law- comparing two-block systems

content.question: A block of mass <math alttext="M sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> is on a horizontal surface and attached by a string to a hanging block, also of mass <math alttext="M sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, as shown in the figure. Friction between the block and the horizontal surface is negligible. The masses of the string and pulley are negligible, and the pulley can rotate with negligible friction around its axle. When the hanging block is released, it has an acceleration of magnitude <math alttext="a sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>a</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. A second trial is performed after replacing the hanging block with a different block of mass <math alttext="3 M sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><msub><mi>M</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. The hanging block of mass <math alttext="3 M sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><msub><mi>M</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> has an acceleration of magnitude <math alttext="a sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> after being released. What is the ratio <math alttext="the fraction with numerator a sub 2, and denominator a sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><msub><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi>a</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mfrac></math>?

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
